Probably related to Bug #75046. Launching w/o jdt.debug in workspace (and therefore getting jdi.jar in 
the bootclasspath instead of the class files) works fine

Jeff, when the org.eclipse.jdt.debug plugin is in the workspace, I put its bin 
folder on the bootclasspath.  Otherwise, I put its JAR.

Would the bin classes be interfering with the runtime classloader?

After talking to Jeff, here is what is going on:
When the jdt.debug plugin is in source form, the output from all its source 
folders goes into one bin folder.  So when PDE puts the bin folder of said 
plugin on the boot classpath, it is the boot classpath that will load any 
class from jdt.debug, (ie. from both jdimodel.jar as well as jdi.jar).  When 
it tries to load a class from jdimodel.jar, it will run into classloading 
problems because it does not have enough knowledge to go into jdt.debug's 
prereqs and load other classes (e.g. org.eclipse.debug.core.model.IBreakpoint) 
in this case.

What I will do for now is put jdi.jar on the classpath from the external 
jdt.debug plugin if jdt.debug is in source form in the workspace.
A better, yet equally unclean, solution would be for the JDT/Debug team to 
have the source for jdi.jar compile into a separate output folder than the 
rest of the code in that plugin.
Fixed as per previous comment.  Thanks Jeff.
